nodes.bodyText: I was passing by and wanted to ask how is it possible to get var Type in PMD? In that case var variable is just ignored, right?

If the variable type is inferred, then there is no type node, but the type of the VariableDeclaratorId node may be set anyway, if we can resolve the type of the initializer. In the example above, if Foo is on the classpath, then varId.getType() == InputStream.class
The type of the VariableDeclaratorId is always the "real" type of the variable, provided it's on the classpath and we can resolve it. Manipulating the VariableDeclaratorId is always preferable to testing the type node manually, for reasons explained in the javadoc
OK in that case I believe this pr is good to merge. I'll open an issue as you said

I don't really like that this method is undefined. In PMD 7 we have good type resolution, but this method call, and the variable, would have type TypeSystem.UNKNOWN. If we want to use type resolution in this rule later to improve its precision/generality, we have to use "compilable" code in tests.
You can just define the method in the file, so that typeres can see the signature:
InputStream getInputStreamFromSomewhere() { return null; }

Note that this is not specific to this PR, but really is a common problem in our tests, because often we just copy-paste the test case provided in the issue, where many types are unresolved.
This is a random place to ask: is it a good idea to use var as a variable name?
